title: Understanding the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
text: The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation is used to estimate the pH of a buffer solution. It is given by: pH=pKa+log{10}{(A-/HA)}. Here, pKa is the negative logarithm of the acid dissociation constant (Ka), and A- and HA are the concentrations of the conjugate base and the weak acid, respectively.

title: Calculate pKa from Ka
text: To find pKa, use the formula: $$pKa=-\log_{10}\left(Ka\right)$$. Given that $$Ka=1.8e-5$$, calculate pKa.

title: Determine the Concentration Ratio
text: The concentration ratio of the conjugate base to the weak acid is given by (A-/HA). Use the given moles of A- and HA to find this ratio.

title: Calculate the Concentration Ratio
text: Calculate the concentration ratio using the formula: (A-/HA)=0.0200/0.0300.

title: Apply the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
text: Now that you have pKa and the concentration ratio, substitute these values into the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation: pH=pKa+log{10}{(A-/HA)}.

title: Calculate the pH
text: Substitute the values into the equation: $$pH=4.74+\log_{10}\left(0.6667\right)$$.
